description.plain:
Van Halen is one of the most iconic American rock bands of all time. Formed in Pasadena, California in 1972, the group’s primary line-up consisted of Eddie Van Halen on guitar, Alex Van Halen on drums, David Lee Roth providing lead vocals, and Michael Anthony providing bass duties and significant harmonies.



Their first six albums, recorded and released between 1977–1984, are considered to be classics and pioneering efforts in the field of hard rock. Eddie Van Halen’s groundbreaking guitar sound and techniques completely changed the landscape of music and radio culture in the 1980s. His and brother Alex’s virtuosity, along with David Lee Roth’s charisma and bassist Michael Anthony’s foundational contributions garnered the band early comparisons to their predecessors—Led Zeppelin—a group who had a profound influence on them. Though, even more so than Jimmy Page, Eddie cites Eric Clapton as having the biggest impact on his playing.

In 1977, after recording a demo with Gene Simmons (who wanted the band to change their name to “Daddy Longlegs”) they were introduced to KISS‘ management, who told Simmons they wouldn’t sign them because:

They had no chance of making it…

Eventually, they impressed Ted Templeman of Warner Bros. enough to attract a record deal. Their eponymous debut reached No. 19 on the Billboard Pop Chart with two successful singles: “Runnin' with the Devil” and their cover of The Kink’s “You Really Got Me.”

The success of this album, their sophomore release and subsequent follow-up efforts sparked a glam-rock/hair metal movement that catapulted them to notoriety. Just as the band reached its zenith (after the release and supporting tour for 1984), Roth parted ways, citing creative differences. The timing was uncanny, with the announcement falling on April 1, 1985, leaving many fans in disbelief (thinking it was an April Fool’s Joke).



Roth was soon replaced by Sammy Hagar. Hagar’s tenure, which originally lasted from 1985–1996, provided Van Halen with its only #1 album in the United States: 5150, released in 1986.

Following a brief spell with Van Halen III and singer Gary Cherone in 1998, as well as a disastrous reunion tour with Hagar in 2004, the band reunited with DLR. As of 2015, the group consists of Roth, Eddie, Alex, and Eddie’s son (Wolfgang Van Halen) on bass—although, rumors surrounding a reunion with the original four members began circulating in 2019.



They remain influential to this day. As of 2017, they were ranked at #9 on the list of the Top Ten Best-Selling Rock Bands of All Time in America.

songs.full_title: Jump by Van Halen

body.plain:
“Jump” is the lead single from Van Halen’s 10x platinum selling album 1984. The song was internationally successful, becoming Van Halen’s only #1 hit in both the US & Canada and reaching #2 in Ireland & Australia, #4 in Germany, Austria & Switzerland, and #7 in the UK.

At first, the rest of the band was reluctant to include the song because of its heavy use of synths and lack of prominent guitar. But after Eddie got producer Ted Templeton on board, the rest of the band softened up. The original inspiration for the lyrics came from David Lee Roth watching a person on TV who was threatening to commit suicide by jumping off of a building and Roth figured someone in the crowd must be thinking, “Go ahead and jump”. It was, however, not written about suicide – the song is about ‘jumping’ on the opportunity to hook up with someone.

Also, it has been said that the 82nd Airborne Division (US Army) uses this tune periodically for paratrooper training and operations. “Might as well jump” … before I kick your ass out of the Goddamn door! Intentionally or involuntarily, you’re goin' out!

songs.full_title: Panama by Van Halen

body.plain: The song supposedly started because Van Halen was criticized for songs solely about hard partying, hot women, and fast cars. To which David Lee Roth responds, “I take exception to that. I have never written a song about a fast car. But now that you mention it, good idea!” The car is either a drag racer named Panama Express or Diamond Dave’s Opel Kadet.

songs.full_title: Hot for Teacher by Van Halen

annotatable.link_title: Hot for Teacher by Van Halen
annotatable.title: Hot for Teacher

body.plain:
“Hot For Teacher” was Van Halen’s last single and music video before David Lee Roth’s departure in 1985. It peaked at #58 in the US.

The song tells the tale of a boy who suddenly finds himself paying a lot of attention in class. Or rather, the person teaching it. Its lyrics were inspired by somebody who once worked at Cherry Lawn School, a boarding school in Connecticut David Lee Roth once attended as a child. The outtro of the song was taken from an earlier demo of the song “Voodoo Queen” from 1977.

Tipper Gore, wife of former Vice-President Al Gore, was inspired by the song’s music video to form the PMRC, a committee that advocated putting warning labels on albums with violent, drug-related or sexual themes:

The images frightened my children, they frightened me. The graphic sex and the violence were too much for us to handle.

songs.embed_content: Read “Hot for Teacher” by Van Halen on Genius

songs.full_title: Ain't Talkin' 'Bout Love by Van Halen

annotatable.link_title: Ain’t Talkin’ ’Bout Love by Van Halen
annotatable.title: Ain't Talkin' 'Bout Love

body.plain: A song about showing dominance over a woman, which soon became one of Van Halen’s most iconic. Eddie stated it was supposed to be a punk parody, “a stupid thing to us, just two chords”.

songs.full_title: Runnin' with the Devil by Van Halen

annotatable.link_title: Runnin’ with the Devil by Van Halen
annotatable.title: Runnin' with the Devil

body.plain: This is the opening track from Van Halen’s eponymous debut album. It was also their second single. It opens with a car-horn sample comprised of each band member’s own vehicle connected to a footswitch. Ted Templeman slowed the audio down, and faded it in at the beginning. This intro would also be used on the demo version of the song “House of Pain.”

songs.full_title: Right Now by Van Halen

body.plain: Van Halen tells listeners to seize the day, in what Sammy Hagar described as his best lyrics for the band. It’s famous for the music video reflecting on events that were occurring at the time, both within the band and out in the world around them.

album.full_title: For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge by Van Halen

songs.full_title: Eruption by Van Halen

body.plain:
“Eruption” is one of the most famous instrumentals of all time, showcasing Eddie Van Halen’s signature tapping techniques.  Guitar World magazine ranked it at number two on their list of greatest guitar solos of all time.

There’s a reason it opens both of Van Halen’s greatest hits albums: 1996’s Best Of – Volume I and 2004’s Best of Both Worlds. Some live renditions can extend to upwards of ten minutes, and often it segues into “You Really Got Me,” just like on their original 1978 debut album:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_lwocmL9dQ

The piece is sometimes combined with elements from Eddie’s other recorded solos, 1979’s “Spanish Fly” and 1982’s “Little Guitars (Intro).”

songs.embed_content: Read “Eruption” by Van Halen on Genius

The piece is sometimes combined with elements from Eddie’s other recorded solos, 1979’s “Spanish Fly” and 1982’s “Little Guitars (Intro).”

songs.full_title: You Really Got Me by Van Halen

annotatable.link_title: You Really Got Me by Van Halen
annotatable.title: You Really Got Me

body.plain:
This is a cover of a song by The Kinks. When original writer Ray Davies was interviewed by MassLive in 2009, he said:

I […] liked the Van Halen version of ‘You Really Got Me,’ because it made me laugh. It was like playing with Metallica. It was all done with good spirit and good humor, it made me smile. That’s the key thing.

His brother Dave Davies, on the other hand, showed contempt in a separate 2010 Pulse of Radio report:

There’s the thing: good art isn’t always about having the comfiest technique. I shouldn’t encourage him, but I’m sure Eddie Van Halen played better when he was drunk. But it must be a good record if people like it. [Their] version was very Middle America. It was like, ‘Hey man, look at me with my tight trousers! Here’s our version of 'You Really Got Me’!

It predates Van Halen’s 1978 eponymous debut album by a month, being released as a single alongside “Atomic Punk” in January of that year.

annotatable.link_title: Why Can’t This Be Love by Van Halen
annotatable.title: Why Can't This Be Love

body.plain: The first single by “Van Hagar”, “Why Can’t This Be Love” is synth-driven and has lyrics recalling the feelings felt at the touch of an unrequited lover. It shot up to #3 on the Hot 100.

songs.full_title: Unchained by Van Halen

body.plain:
Despite not being released as a single in the US, “Unchained” peaked at #13 on the Rock Chart in the summer of 1981. The song was released as a single in a few countries overseas, but had no chart impact there.

It was originally titled “Hit The Ground Running” and is their only song to feature the voice of long-time VH producer Ted Templeton, who delivers the line “Come on, Dave, give me a break”.

While Van Halen made no standard promotional music videos for Fair Warning, three live recordings from its tour (captured two months after the album’s release) were shown on MTV, with “Unchained” being one of them.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQgHvOvujNE

songs.full_title: Jamie's Cryin' by Van Halen

body.plain:
“Jamie’s Cryin'” is the sixth song on Van Halen’s first album with the same name as the band. The album was released on February 10, 1978. The album would go on to reach #19 on the Billboard 200

The song tells the story of a girl named Jamie who has a one night stand with a nameless boy. Jamie goes on to regret this decision and tries to make things work with the boy.  As she tries and tries things get progressively worse. The song is reminiscent of the classic high school love story.

songs.full_title: Love Walks In by Van Halen

annotatable.link_title: Love Walks In by Van Halen
annotatable.title: Love Walks In

songs.embed_content: Read “Love Walks In” by Van Halen on Genius
songs.lyrics:
Contact is all it takes
To change your life to lose your place in time
Contact! Asleep or awake
Coming around you may wake up to find
Questions deep within your eyes
Now more than ever, you realize

And then you sense a change
Nothing feels the same
All your dreams are strange
Love comes walkin' in
Some kind of alien
Waits for the opening
Then simply pulls a string

Another world, some other time
You lay your sanity on the line
Familiar faces familiar sights
Reach back, remember with all your might
Ooh, there she stands in a silken gown
Silver lights shining down

And then you sense a change
Nothing feels the same
All your dreams are strange
Love comes walkin' in
Some kind of alien
Waits for the opening
Then simply pulls a string
Love comes walkin' in


Ah, sleep and dream, that's all I crave
I travel far across the Milky Way
To my master I become a slave
Til we meet again some other day
Where silence speaks as loud as war
Earth returns to what it was before

And then you sense a change
Nothing feels the same
All your dreams are strange
Love comes walkin' in
Some kind of alien
Waits for the opening
Then simply pulls a string
Love comes walkin' in
songs.title: Love Walks In

body.plain:
Van Halen is one of the most iconic American rock bands of all time. Formed in Pasadena, California in 1972, the group’s primary line-up consisted of Eddie Van Halen on guitar, Alex Van Halen on drums, David Lee Roth providing lead vocals, and Michael Anthony providing bass duties and significant harmonies.



Their first six albums, recorded and released between 1977–1984, are considered to be classics and pioneering efforts in the field of hard rock. Eddie Van Halen’s groundbreaking guitar sound and techniques completely changed the landscape of music and radio culture in the 1980s. His and brother Alex’s virtuosity, along with David Lee Roth’s charisma and bassist Michael Anthony’s foundational contributions garnered the band early comparisons to their predecessors—Led Zeppelin—a group who had a profound influence on them. Though, even more so than Jimmy Page, Eddie cites Eric Clapton as having the biggest impact on his playing.

In 1977, after recording a demo with Gene Simmons (who wanted the band to change their name to “Daddy Longlegs”) they were introduced to KISS‘ management, who told Simmons they wouldn’t sign them because:

They had no chance of making it…

Eventually, they impressed Ted Templeman of Warner Bros. enough to attract a record deal. Their eponymous debut reached No. 19 on the Billboard Pop Chart with two successful singles: “Runnin' with the Devil” and their cover of The Kink’s “You Really Got Me.”

The success of this album, their sophomore release and subsequent follow-up efforts sparked a glam-rock/hair metal movement that catapulted them to notoriety. Just as the band reached its zenith (after the release and supporting tour for 1984), Roth parted ways, citing creative differences. The timing was uncanny, with the announcement falling on April 1, 1985, leaving many fans in disbelief (thinking it was an April Fool’s Joke).



Roth was soon replaced by Sammy Hagar. Hagar’s tenure, which originally lasted from 1985–1996, provided Van Halen with its only #1 album in the United States: 5150, released in 1986.

Following a brief spell with Van Halen III and singer Gary Cherone in 1998, as well as a disastrous reunion tour with Hagar in 2004, the band reunited with DLR. As of 2015, the group consists of Roth, Eddie, Alex, and Eddie’s son (Wolfgang Van Halen) on bass—although, rumors surrounding a reunion with the original four members began circulating in 2019.



They remain influential to this day. As of 2017, they were ranked at #9 on the list of the Top Ten Best-Selling Rock Bands of All Time in America.
